Anyone else feeling concerned right now? 

I have been reading about the recent decisions by companies likeandto scale back their Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (DEI) programmes.

Inclusion is something I view as vital not only in business, but in society.

Looking ahead, surely this ‚Äúscaling back‚Äù has the potential to lead to multiple harmful outcomes:

Reduced workforce diversity - which in turn may limit the variety of perspectives and ideas which are essential for innovation and problem-solving.

Damage to company reputation - especially amongst consumers and business partners who prioritise DEI and social responsibility (perhaps these businesses are so big that it doesn‚Äôt matter‚Ä¶)

 Decreased employee morale and engagement - particularly from underrepresented groups and their allies.

 Legal and compliance risks - in relation to equality, which may leave businesses exposed to claims of discrimination.

 Increased turnover rates - a costly and time-consuming issue to remedy.

‚Äôs full article can be found here 



I know I‚Äôm not the only person who feels uneasy about all of this.

To quote, author of ‚ÄúUnwavering‚Äù and a prominent DEI advocate:

"Diversity is a fact, but inclusion is a choice we make every day. As leaders, we have to put out the message that we embrace, and not just tolerate, diversity."

Like many others, I will watch this space with trepidation.

In the meantime,will continue to champion change, raise awareness and keep building an inclusive culture.



[ Image is taken from an article in The Guardian from 10 January. It shows a man in a blue t-shirt called Mark Zuckerberg with the headline ‚ÄúMeta terminates its DEI programs days before Trump inauguration.‚Äù]

I think we need to change the ‚Äúcharged‚Äù narrative around DEI. 

Those that consider it woke have jumped on it as a divisive, specific agenda-led initiative. 

However from where I sit - at its core - it is about taking the time to think about and understand humans from different backgrounds, heritages, communities. To enable us to attract, develop and grow the best talent. This leads to diversity of people and even more important - diversity of thought/ideas that will grow your business.

Who wants to shut that down?

Voices of Courage: Individuals Willing to Share Their Journeys




Recently, I engaged with a member of the LinkedIn community who raised significant concerns regarding the current screening and interviewing methodologies employed by a percentage of today‚Äôs hiring managers.

He shared his experience, which initially seemed promising but devolved into a discouraging series of lengthy interviews followed by rejection due to an automated system. This scenario leads me to question whether this indicates a broader trend within the hiring landscape or merely an anomaly.

I am curious how many Green Banners members have encountered similar challenges.

Throughout my professional journey, I have navigated favorable and challenging interview situations (
) with various organizations. At times, it has felt as though a preferred candidate was predetermined, a sentiment that became apparent after navigating a protracted interview process.

This recurring pattern leads me to wonder whether these experiences represent a widespread trend or are exceptions.

I invite those who feel comfortable to contribute their experiences. I recognize that it may be daunting to speak out, but your willingness to share may contribute significantly to our understanding of this concern.

posts.content:
My screen froze 2 minutes before my first big client pitch. 
3 days of preparation was falling apart in front of my eyes.

This was my first major pitch as a content director.
Everything was riding on this moment.

I had 3 days preparing for this pitch.
I perfected every slide and practiced every line.

It was an opportunity to shine in the company.
It was a chance to win over a major client.

But now, I was staring at a frozen screen.
Left wondering if I was about to blow it.

I had two choices.
Panic or adapt.

I grabbed my phone.
Called the client directly and explained the situation.

I apologized for the inconvenience.
And I offered to walk them through the pitch verbally
while my team emailed the deck to the client.

To my relief, he agreed.

By the end of the call, the client was laughing.
Thanking me for my transparency and quick thinking.

I luckily got our client on board.

That day and incident taught me an important lesson.

Adaptability is one of the most underrated skills in professional life.

Things won‚Äôt always go as planned.
However, how you respond in those moments can define you.

Now, I make a point to prepare for the unexpected.

When you prepare for everything.
You are startled by nothing.

Have you ever had to think on your feet during a crisis?
I‚Äôd love to hear how you handled it.

comments.commentText: Great example of adapting to the circumstance and thinking on your feet !
